prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 253-1536: [CI]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [CI] is the primary target, with a bright CS 10-9 line nearby to compare to existing CS 7-6 (complemented by this dataset). There are a number of potentially strong organics lines that we have targeted, specifically a formaldehyde isotopologue, numerous CH3OH lines and a HCCCH line, which is known to be one of the brightest emission lines in T Tauri disks.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The channel width is set to resolve the Keplerian disk rotation across the line which is necessary to confirm disk vs. foreground cloud emission. Obtaining disk rotation information for this particular proplyd is also useful for isolating emission from each component of disk binary system, which are mostly spatially resolved, but fully spectrally resolved.

We have set our imaging parameters to approximately match the angular resolution of the original survey (PI Mann) with the intention to integrate deeper to detect CI and the isotopes of CO and HCO+. We are also limited by the need for high frequency (Band 8) observations and the RA of the source (Orion is RA of 5h), and so the ideal configuration for these observations is C36-2, where Orion is available during the nighttime LST and the beam is still sufficiently large, 0.33". At this resolution, the binary is mostly spatially resolved and fully spectrally resolved.

The primary goal for this spectral setting is to detect [CI]. To estimate the [CI] 3P1-3P0 flux from these disks, we take the [CI] detection in DM Tau of 6.5 Jy km/s (Tsukagoshi et al. 2015) and scale the flux to the distance of Orion, i.e., (140/400)**2. Both proplyds have similar masses to DM Tau and so this provides a useful estimate. At the proposed resolution (0.33''), the peak emission within the beam will be the size of the beam over the size of the disk 0.33/1.25 (for centrally peaked emission, with R^-1). This yields a peak flux of 45 mJy, and so we set our sensivity requirement (11mJy) to measure 4 sigma peak flux, and sqrt(5.0/0.6)=3x higher integrated over the line, or 12 sigma. We emphasize that this is likely a lower limit as [CI]/CO should be enhanced compared to DM Tau under the high external UV conditions, and at least for 253-1536, the disk is a binary and so this number could be a factor of two higher depending on properties of the second disk around the more massive star (albeit with the less massive disk).
We are able to also predict the brightness of the CS 10-9 line based upon the original CS 7-6 observations in 253-1536. The 7-6 line was 54 mJy, and based upon a simple Radex model we expect the 10-9 line to be at least this bright if not brighter (the 10-9 is expected to be stronger than the 7-6 for typical disk-like conditions), and so we should be able to get a >4 sigma detection and 3x higher (12 sigma) on the integrated line flux.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 253-1536: 13CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 13CO 3-2, C18O 3-2, and CN 3-2 are the primary targets of this spectral configuration. There are a C15N line in the band which can be used to check the CN opacity. An HC18O+ line also exists in the band which will help quantify the H13CO+ opacity in the third spectral set-up.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The channel width is set to resolve the Keplerian disk rotation across the line which is necessary to confirm disk vs. foreground cloud emission. The FWHM of the line is about 5-6 km/s, while emission from the disk is detected out to +- 5 km/s in the original survey, and so we will potentially be able to average over 10 km/s, i.e. a sqrt(10/0.44)~5x improvement in sensitivity.

We have set our imaging parameters to approximately match the angular resolution of the original survey (PI Mann), however we are also limited by the need for high frequency (Band 7) observations and the RA of the source (Orion is RA of 5h), and so the ideal configuration for these observations is C36-2, where Orion is available during the nighttime LST and the beam is still sufficiently large, 0.53". At this resolution, the binary is mostly spatially resolved and fully spectrally resolved.

We aim to detect 13CO from this source. CO 3-2 was detected, however the line center velocity is contaminated by emission from the cloud for both proplyds. If we focus on detecting the bright emission in the wings, we can first estimate the expected opacity from another disk for which we have 13CO 2-1 and CO 2-1 data, TW Hya. The 13CO is a factor of 6.3x fainter than the CO due to CO 2-1's high opacity. Taking the observed peak flux of CO 3-2 in the wings (1.3 Jy) and dividing it by 6.3 yields 217 mJy. With these observations, we should be able to achieve a signal to noise of 20 at the line peak, and 100 integrated over the line. In case the 13CO 3-2 is optically thick, we have also included C18O, which if thin, should be ~30 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 253-1536: H13CO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: H13CO+, DCO+ and H13CN are the primary targets of this band. We will also obtain a relatively high spectral resolution CO 3-2 observation, to better quantify CO emission in the wings where the cloud does not emit. We also target organics lines, including a C2H line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The channel width is set to resolve the Keplerian disk rotation across the line which is necessary to confirm disk vs. foreground cloud emission. The FWHM of the line is about 5-6 km/s, while emission from the disk is detected out to +- 5 km/s in the original survey, and so we will potentially be able to average over 10 km/s, i.e. a sqrt(10/0.84)~3.5x improvement in sensitivity. Resolving rotation will also help isolate line emission from each of the disks in the binary.

We have set our imaging parameters to approximately match the angular resolution of the original survey (PI Mann), however we are also limited by the need for high frequency (Band 7) observations and the RA of the source (Orion is RA of 5h), and so the ideal configuration for these observations is C36-2, where Orion is available during the nighttime LST and the beam is still sufficiently large, 0.5". At this resolution, the binary is mostly spatially resolved and fully spectrally resolved.

We primarily aim to detect H13CO+ 4-3. The original survey covered HCO+ 4-3 and was relatively free from envelope contamination. We have estimated the effects of line opacity by applying the measured flux ratio from TW Hya, where HCO+ 4-3/H13CO+ 4-3 ~ 21. The observed peak flux of HCO+ 4-3 is 1.15 Jy, and so we expect the H13CO+ to be 54 mJy at line center, and so with an rms noise of 5 mJy we anticipate a ~10 sigma detection on the peak flux with a 35 sigma detection on the integrated line flux. If external high energy ionizing photons/particles play a major role, the HCO+ abundance (and emission) will likely be higher for both proplyds.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 216-0939: [CI]
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: [CI] is the primary target, with a bright CS 10-9 line nearby to compare to existing CS 7-6 (complemented by this dataset). There are a number of potentially strong organics lines that we have targeted, specifically a formaldehyde isotopologue, numerous CH3OH lines and a HCCCH line, which is known to be one of the brightest emission lines in T Tauri disks.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The channel width is set to resolve the Keplerian disk rotation across the line which is necessary to confirm disk vs. foreground cloud emission. The FWHM of the line is about 5-6 km/s, while emission from the disk is detected out to +- 5 km/s in the original survey, and so we will potentially be able to average over 10 km/s, i.e. a sqrt(10/0.6)~4x improvement in sensitivity.

We have set our imaging parameters to approximately match the angular resolution of the original survey (PI Mann) with the intention to integrate deeper to detect CI and the isotopes of CO and HCO+. We are also limited by the need for high frequency (Band 8) observations and the RA of the source (Orion is RA of 5h), and so the ideal configuration for these observations is C36-2, where Orion is available during the nighttime LST and the beam is still sufficiently large, 0.33".

We have made the same estimate as for 253-1536, where we have taken the measured DM Tau CI 3P1-3P0 flux and scaled it to Orion, and corrected for the beam. See the 253-1536: [CI] science goal's technical justification for details.
We are able to also predict the brightness of the CS 10-9 line based upon the original CS 7-6 observations in the same source. The 7-6 line was 50 mJy, and based upon a simple Radex model we expect the 10-9 line to be at least this bright if not brighter (the 10-9 is stronger than the 7-6), and so we should be able to get a >4 sigma detection and 3x higher on the integrated line flux.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 216-0939: 13CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 13CO 3-2, C18O 3-2, and CN 3-2 are the primary targets of this spectral configuration. There are a C15N line in the band which can be used to check the CN opacity. An HC18O+ line also exists in the band which will help quantify the H13CO+ opacity in the third spectral set-up.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The channel width is set to resolve the Keplerian disk rotation across the line which is necessary to confirm disk vs. foreground cloud emission. The FWHM of the line is about 5-6 km/s, while emission from the disk is detected out to +- 5 km/s in the original survey, and so we will potentially be able to average over 10 km/s, i.e. a sqrt(10/0.44)~5x improvement in sensitivity.

We have set our imaging parameters to approximately match the angular resolution of the original survey (PI Mann), however we are also limited by the need for high frequency (Band 7) observations and the RA of the source (Orion is RA of 5h), and so the ideal configuration for these observations is C36-2, where Orion is available during the nighttime LST and the beam is still sufficiently large, 0.53".

We aim to detect 13CO from this source. CO 3-2 was detected, however the line center velocity is contaminated by emission from the cloud for both proplyds. If we focus on detecting the bright emission in the wings, we can first estimate the expected opacity from another disk for which we have 13CO 2-1 and CO 2-1 data, TW Hya. The 13CO is a factor of 6.3x fainter than the CO due to CO 2-1's high opacity. Taking the observed peak flux of CO 3-2 in the wings (0.38 Jy) and dividing it by 6.3 yields 65 mJy. With these observations, we should be able to achieve a signal to noise of 13 at the line peak, and 65 integrated over the line. In case the 13CO 3-2 is optically thick, we have also included C18O, which if thin, should be ~11 mJy (2 sigma peak) and will only be detected if 13CO is thin (i.e., this line provides an opacity check).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 216-0939: H13CO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: H13CO+, DCO+ and H13CN are the primary targets of this band. We will also obtain a relatively high spectral resolution CO 3-2 observation, to better quantify CO emission in the wings where the cloud does not emit. We also target organics lines, including a C2H line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The channel width is set to resolve the Keplerian disk rotation across the line which is necessary to confirm disk vs. foreground cloud emission. The FWHM of the line is about 5-6 km/s, while emission from the disk is detected out to +- 5 km/s in the original survey, and so we will potentially be able to average over 10 km/s, i.e. a sqrt(10/0.84)~3.5x improvement in sensitivity.

We have set our imaging parameters to approximately match the angular resolution of the original survey (PI Mann), however we are also limited by the need for high frequency (Band 7) observations and the RA of the source (Orion is RA of 5h), and so the ideal configuration for these observations is C36-2, where Orion is available during the nighttime LST and the beam is still sufficiently large, 0.5".

We primarily aim to detect H13CO+ 4-3. The original survey covered HCO+ 4-3 and was relatively free from envelope contamination. We have estimated the effects of line opacity by applying the measured flux ratio from TW Hya, where HCO+ 4-3/H13CO+ 4-3 ~ 21. The observed peak flux of HCO+ 4-3 is 0.17 Jy, and so we expect the H13CO+ to be 8 mJy at line center, and so with an rms noise of 2 mJy we anticipate a 4 sigma detection on the peak with a 14 sigma detection on the integrated line flux. The flux may be fainter as propyld 216-0939 is a factor of two more distant from theta Ori C than 253-1536 (weaker external radiation field), hence the need to go deeper.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Most planetary systems (including our own) form in young stellar clusters in the presence of massive, luminous stars where high energy radiation fields and energetic cosmic rays are known to be significantly elevated over local interstellar conditions. This harsh environment can potentially impact the physical structure and chemistry of the evolving protoplanetary disks, and correspondingly, the planets formed within them. We propose to characterize the chemical compositions of two known gas-rich proplyds on the outskirts of the Orion Nebula Cluster. These systems provide our closest known analogues to the conditions present during the Solar System's formation. We target a suite of lines that are particularly sensitive to the external UV and X-ray radiation fields to shed light on how the disk chemistry/physical properties (ionization, temperature, composition) evolve within this extreme environment.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
